thread.title: Air New Zealand Boeing 737 makes final flying visit to Invercargill
thread.title_full: Air New Zealand Boeing 737 makes final flying visit to Invercargill

author: Dave Nicoll
title: Air New Zealand Boeing 737 makes final flying visit to Invercargill
text:
Air New Zealand Boeing 737 makes final flying visit to Invercargill DAVE NICOLL Last updated 18:34, September 8 2015 JOHN HAWKINS/FAIRFAX NZ 
The Boeing 737 is farewelled at the Invercargill airport on Tuesday. 
It's the end of an era for the 737. 
Since 1968, the 737 has served in the Air New Zealand fleet, taking many Kiwis on their first jet flight. 
Just under 700 people turned out at the Invercargill airport on Tuesday to say goodbye to the old bird. JOHN HAWKINS/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN HAWKINS/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN HAWKINS/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN HAWKINS/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN HAWKINS/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN HAWKINS/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN HAWKINS/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN HAWKINS/FAIRFAX NZ 
Air New Zealands 737 Final Call at Invercargill Airport 
Owen MacAskill lines up for a look through Air New Zealands 737 Final Call at Invercargill Airport 
St Joseph's School head boy Thomas Knight 10yrs has the aircraft controls explained by First Officer Gus Black during Air New Zealand's 737 Final Call at Invercargill Airport. 
Air NZ Captain Graeme Mollison chats to New River Primary student Ruby Forbs 8, Eden Dallas 8 and Mahalia Katuke 9 with teacher Lorraine Dallas during Air New Zealands 737 Final Call at Invercargill Airport 
08092015News. John Hawkins/Fairfax NZ Russell Evans and Owen MacAskill checking out the engine intake during Air New Zealands 737 Final Call at Invercargill Airport 
08092015News. John Hawkins/Fairfax NZ Public line up for a look through Air New Zealands 737 Final Call at Invercargill Airport 
08092015News. John Hawkins/Fairfax NZ James Hargest Junior students L/R Tylee Fiebig 12, Talia Stout 11 and Jessica Burtenshaw 11 checking out Air New Zealands 737 Final Call at Invercargill Airport 
08092015News. John Hawkins/Fairfax NZ James Hargest Juniors students enjoying a visit during Air New Zealands 737 Final Call at Invercargill Airport 1 of 8 « Previous « Previous Next » Next » 
Air New Zealand 737 fleet manager first officer Gus Black said the 737 was an iconic aircraft around the world. 
"Air New Zealand had been operating them for 47 years. Tens of thousands of staff had worked on these aircraft." 
Most New Zealanders would have had their first jet flight on a 737, he said. 
Black had been flying the 737 for seven years since he joined Air New Zealand in 2008. 
In 1998 they upgraded from the 737-200 to the newer version of the jet, the 737-300, Black said. 
"It's just like buying an old Holden Commodore versus a newer one. We upgraded. Faster, more efficient, bigger. Just a better version of the old one." 
Since then the airline has operated a total of 23 737-300s, he said. Ad Feedback 
"The last two 737's we've got are the last two ever built by Boeing. This was the second to last." 
The planes still could operate for another 10 years and would be sold off to other airlines overseas, Black said. 
"These are pretty desirable. They're not a new aeroplane but they are pretty capable." 
"It's old technology bit it still works great." 
The Boeing 737 would be replaced by the Airbus A320, which were around 15 percent more fuel efficient, he said. 
Air New Zealand wanted more efficient, bigger planes that would provide a better experience for passengers, Black said. 
"When you're burning as much fuel as an airline does that's a massive improvement." 
It's the end of an era, Black said. 
Air New Zealand 737 Flight Instructor captain Geoff Rowe who had been flying the 737 for 22 years said a lot of the pilots were quite fond of the 737 planes. 
Rowe compared the jets to and old Holden or Ford V8. 
"We'd still like to hang on to the old V8." 
Rowe said he would be moving to the Airbus fleet where there was a position held for him. 
In September NAC – which merged with Air New Zealand in 1978 – took delivery of its first Boeing 737-200, and operated its first commercial flight in October between Auckland and Wellington. 
Air New Zealand's 737-200 fleet made more than 825,000 flights during its 33 years with the airline. - Stuff
